awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Collaborative Research: Fire regime influences on carbon dynamics of Siberian boreal forests
awd_abstract_narration:
Boreal forests cover 40% of the vegetated land area above the Arctic Circle and are a critical component of arctic ecosystems. Global change models predict boreal forests will become increasingly susceptible to fire activity with climate warming. Because these forests contain a large proportion of global terrestrial carbon (C) stocks, changes in the fire regime are likely to alter global C cycling. Increased fire activity will increase C emissions to the atmosphere, with a potential positive feedback to climate warming. However, an altered fire regime may also initiate cascading effects on forest regrowth and permafrost degradation that could magnify or offset this feedback. Fire effects on these ecological mechanisms remain uncertain but will ultimately determine whether arctic ecosystems act as a C source or sink under future climate change scenarios. The primary objective of this research is to increase our understanding of post-fire C dynamics in boreal forests of the Siberian arctic by elucidating the ecological mechanisms by which increased fire severity could influence C accumulation and storage over the successional interval. The overarching hypothesis is that post-fire soil organic layer (SOL) depth regulates net ecosystem carbon balance (NECB) through indirect impacts on forest regrowth and permafrost stability because of its role as a barrier to seed germination and thermal regulator. The team will: 1) link near term fire effects on SOL depth to changes in larch recruitment and permafrost characteristics in experimental burn plots created in 2012, 2) determine the relationship between post-fire stand structure and above- and belowground C pools at the local and landscape level across stands of varying age and topographic positions, and 3) test via experimental manipulations and field observations the mechanisms by which fire-driven changes in stand density indirectly affect moss growth, SOL development, and susceptibility of deeper C pools to warming, decomposition, and release into the atmosphere. This research will offer novel insights into the importance of both vegetation and soil processes within arctic ecosystems in determining the net feedback of an intensified fire regime to the climate system.

Intellectual Merit: Larch forests of the Siberian arctic comprise 20% of all boreal forest ecosystems and are distinct from other boreal forests in that they consist of a single tree genus (Larix spp.) with a deciduous growth habit and often grow on continuous, C-rich ?yedoma? permafrost. Thus, their response to warming climate and an altered fire regime is likely to differ from boreal forests in other regions. Uncertainties regarding current C pools in Siberian boreal forests remain a significant factor affecting our ability to predict climate-induced changes to the global C cycle. The proposed study will contribute to our understanding of how arctic forest fires impact global C cycling and provide essential data necessary for scaling-up arctic C pools, estimating C emissions from arctic fires, and calibrating predictive models of future global C cycling.

Broader Impacts: This project will result in the training of undergraduate and graduate students from two predominantly undergraduate institutions and one Hispanic-Serving Institution. The PI and her students will develop outreach activities with local K-12 schools in south Texas to help teachers create lesson plans involving arctic science, boreal ecology, and climate change and involve researcher presentations to science classrooms to provide real-life examples of arctic research and expose K-12 students to different career and educational paths in the sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Boreal forests cover large portions of the Arctic, store massive amounts of carbon in vegetation and soils, and are increasingly susceptible to wildfire with climate warming. Larger and more severe fires will likely alter rates of carbon accumulation and longer term carbon storage in boreal forests. Siberian boreal forests are ecologically unique because they are dominated by deciduous needleleaf trees, and there is less know about how fire severity affects carbon storage in these ecosystems. This aim of this project was characterize how fire severity affects carbon storage in boreal forests in the Siberian arctic.

A key finding of the project was that more larch seedlings sprout in areas burned more severely.  To determine this small 2m x 2m plots were burned at different levels of severity, and over the next several years larch seeds were sown and the plots were monitored. In the plots subject to more severe burning more organic soil was combusted. The number of larch seedlings to germinate was increased with the amount of organic soil combusted in the fire. This implies that more severe fires may lead to denser forest that store more carbon in tree biomass.

To test this idea and quantify how changes in forest density affect ecosystem carbon storage, field measurements were made in over thirty mature forest stands (30m x 30m area). Most of these stands were in an area that burned 70 years ago, and analysis of tree rings revealed the average tree age was 55 years in all of the stands. Forest density in these stands was highly variable, ranging from less than 0.5 to nearly 4 trees per square meter. Consequently, there was a large difference in the amount of biomass stored in trees in these forest. However, there was much more carbon in soils, and sparser forests had more biomass in understory shrubs, grasses, and mosses. So the total amount of carbon stored in these ecosystems did not increase with tree density.

Analyses of additional field and satellite data resulted in several additional important findings. First, satellite data showed that denser forests create a darker land surface that creates a warming effect by absorbing more solar radiation. Second, tree ring analyses revealed that denser forests do not respond as positively to warm temperatures, probably due to competition for resources between individual trees. Related, additional field measurements showed that larch trees experience drought stress during warm and dry periods, and that these trees are limited by nitrogen, with a potential interaction between water and nutrient dynamics. Taken together these results indicate that the effects of fire and stand density may feedback to climate through effects on surface energy dynamics, and that how these ecosystems respond to climate will likely be controlled by complex interactions between competition, hydrology, and plant nutrition.

In addition to these important findings, this project provided scientific training for 10 undergraduate students, 9 masters-level students, 1 PhD student, and 3 post-doctoral researchers. The project has resulted in 14 peer-reviewed publications, and project results and data have been integrated in at least 10 university courses, numerous invited lectures, and nearly 20 media outlets. Project data are freely available via public data repositories and have already been utilized in several data-synthesis studies and for satellite data processing algorithm development and testing. Project personnel collaborated with one high school science teacher, who participated in field work as part of the project, and subsequently hosted a project PI and students at their school. Lastly, this project fostered continued development of now longstanding collaborative relationships between US and Russian scientist.
